titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Center for Constitutional Rights Records TAM.589
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-11-25T11:26-0500

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

did.physloc: Materials in this collection are stored offsite and advance notice is required for their use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least two business days prior to visiting the library.
did.abstract: The Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) is a non-profit legal advocacy organization based in New York City. The Center was initially established to provide legal services and financial support to lawyers representing civil rights movement activists in Mississippi, but has since broaded its focus to civil liberties and human rights activism and litigation more generally. This unprocessed collection of records created or collected by CCR consists of correspondence, political ephemera, newspaper clippings, research files, and legal documents, including briefs, motions, and trial transcripts documenting the organization's legal advocacy.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Center for Constitutional Rights (New York, N.Y.).

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by the Center for Constitutional Rights are held by the Center for Constitutional Rights. Permission to publish or reproduce materials to which s/he holds copyright must be secured from the copyright holder. Please contact the Tamiment Library for assistance with contacting donor.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The order in which these materials were sent to the Tamiment Library has been maintained.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) is a non-profit legal advocacy organization based on New York City. It was founded in 1966 by civil rights lawyers and legal activists, including William Kuntsler, Morton Stavis, Arthur Kinoy, and Ben Smith. The Center was initially established to provide legal services and financial support to lawyers representing civil rights movement activists in Mississippi. Since then, CCR has broadened its focus to civil liberties and human rights activism and litigation more generally, providing legal assistance to a variety of clients, including Guantanamo Bay detainment camp prisoners and victims of racial profiling in the wake of 9/11.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All boxes in this collection must be reviewed for restrictions concerning privileged or confidential materials prior to research use. Materials in boxes 1-184 must be reviewed by an archivist; materials in boxes 185-246 must be reviewed by both an archivist and a representative from the Center for Constitutional Rights. Please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu at least one week prior to research visit to allow time for this review.

custodhist.head: Custodial History note
custodhist.p: The Center for Constitutional Rights donated their records to the New York Public Library’s Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. In August of 2012, 184 record cartons of CCR materials were transferred from NYPL and deeded to Tamiment Library (accession number 2012.065); in September of 2012, CCR donated an additional accession of approximately 50 boxes to Tamiment (accession number 2011.114).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Center for Constitutional Rights Records; TAM 589; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. A box-level inventory has been imported to provide basic description of the materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This unprocessed collection of records created or collected by the Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR) consists of correspondence, political ephemera, newspaper clippings, research files, and legal documents, including briefs, motions, and trial transcripts documenting the organization's legal advocacy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Center for Constitutional Rights (CCR), founded in 1966 by attorneys who represented civil rights movements in the South, is dedicated to advancing and protecting the rights guaranteed by the United States Constitution and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. CCR is a non-profit legal and educational organization committed to the use of law as a force for social change. Some issues CCR works on is illegal detention and Guantanamo, surveillance and attacks on dissent, criminal justice and mass incarcerations, corporate human rights abuse, government abuse of power, racial and gender justice, and international law and accountability. The website lists news and current cases
